Joint Universal Lossy Coding and Identification
of Stationary Mixing Sources

Maxim Raginsky Beckman Institute and the University of Illinois
405 N Mathews Ave, Urbana, IL 61801, USA
Email: maxim@uiuc.edu
Abstract

The problem of joint universal source coding and modeling, treated in the context of lossless codes by Rissanen, was recently generalized to fixed-rate lossy coding of finitely parametrized continuous-alphabet i.i.d. sources. We extend these results to variable-rate lossy block coding of stationary ergodic sources and show that, for bounded metric distortion measures, any finitely parametrized family of stationary sources satisfying suitable mixing, smoothness and Vapnik‚ÄìChervonenkis learnability conditions admits universal schemes for joint lossy source coding and identification. We also give several explicit examples of parametric sources satisfying the regularity conditions.

I Introduction

A universal source coding scheme is one that performs asymptotically optimally for all sources within a given class. Intuition suggests that a good universal coder should acquire a probabilistic model of the source from a sufficiently long data sequence and operate based on this model. For lossless codes, this intuition has been made rigorous by Rissanen [1]: the data are encoded via a two-part code which comprises (1) a suitably quantized maximum-likelihood estimate of the source parameters, and (2) an encoding of the data with the code optimized for the acquired model. The redundancy of this scheme converges to zero as k‚Äãlog‚Å°n/nùëòùëõùëõk\log n/n, where nùëõn is the block length and kùëòk is the dimension of the parameter space.

Recently we have extended Rissanen‚Äôs ideas to lossy block coding of finitely parametrized continuous-alphabet i.i.d. sources with bounded parameter spaces [2, 3]. We have shown that, under appropriate regularity conditions, there exist joint universal schemes for lossy coding and source identification whose distortion redundancy and source estimation fidelity both converge to zero as O‚Äã(log‚Å°n/n)ùëÇùëõùëõO\big{(}\sqrt{\log n/n}\big{)} as the block length nùëõn tends to infinity. The code operates by coding each block with the code matched to the parameters estimated from the preceding block. Moreover, the constant hidden in the O‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëÇ‚ãÖO(\cdot) notation increases with the ‚Äúrichness‚Äù of the model class, as measured by the Vapnik‚ÄìChervonenkis (VC) dimension [4, 5] of a certain class of decision regions in the source alphabet.

The main limitation of the results of [2, 3] is the i.i.d. assumption, which excludes such practically relevant model classes as autoregressive sources or Markov and hidden Markov processes. Furthermore, the assumption of a bounded parameter space may not be always justified. In this paper we relax both of these assumptions. Because the parameter space is not bounded, we have to use variable-rate codes with countably infinite codebooks, whose performance is naturally quantified by Lagrangians [6, 7]. We show that, under certain regularity conditions, there are universal schemes for joint lossy source coding and modeling such that, as the block length nùëõn tends to infinity, both the Lagrangian redundancy relative to the best variable-rate code at each block length and the source estimation fidelity at the decoder converge to zero as O‚Äã(Vn‚Äãlog‚Å°n/n)ùëÇsubscriptùëâùëõùëõùëõO(\sqrt{V_{n}\log n/n}), where VnsubscriptùëâùëõV_{n} is the VC dimension of a certain class of decision regions induced by the collection of all nùëõn-dimensional marginals of the source process distributions.

The key novel feature of our scheme is that, unlike most existing schemes for universal lossy coding, which rely on implicit identification of the active source, it learns an explicit probabilistic model. Moreover, our results clearly show that the ‚Äúprice of universality‚Äù of a modeling-based compression scheme grows with the combinatorial richness of the underlying model class, as captured by the VC dimension sequence {Vn}subscriptùëâùëõ\{V_{n}\}. The richer the model class, the harder it is to learn, which in turn affects the compression performance because we use the source parameters learned from past data in deciding how to encode the current block. These insights may prove useful in such settings as digital forensics or adaptive control under communication constraints, where trade-offs between the quality of parameter estimation and compression performance are of central importance.

III The results

In this section we state our result on universal schemes for joint lossy compression and identification of stationary sources satisfying certain regularity conditions. We wish to design a sequence of variable-rate vector quantizers, such that the decoder can reliably reconstruct the source sequence ùëøùëø\boldsymbol{X} and reliably identify the active source in an asymptotically optimal manner for all Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda. The identification performance will be judged in terms of the variational distance, which for any two probability measures P,QùëÉùëÑP,Q on a measurable space (ùíµ,ùíú)ùíµùíú({\cal Z},{\cal A}) is defined by d‚Äã(P,Q)=‚ñ≥2‚ÄãsupA‚ààùíú|P‚Äã(A)‚àíQ‚Äã(A)|superscript‚ñ≥ùëëùëÉùëÑ2subscriptsupremumùê¥ùíúùëÉùê¥ùëÑùê¥d(P,Q)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}2\sup_{A\in{\cal A}}|P(A)-Q(A)|. Denoting by pùëùp and qùëûq the respective densities of PùëÉP and QùëÑQ w.r.t. a dominating measure ŒΩùúà\nu, we can also write d‚Äã(P,Q)=‚à´ùí≥|p‚Äã(z)‚àíq‚Äã(z)|‚ÄãùëëŒΩ‚Äã(z)ùëëùëÉùëÑsubscriptùí≥ùëùùëßùëûùëßdifferential-dùúàùëßd(P,Q)=\int_{\cal X}|p(z)-q(z)|d\nu(z). The set of all QùëÑQ satisfying d‚Äã(P,Q)‚â§Œ¥ùëëùëÉùëÑùõød(P,Q)\leq\delta for a given PùëÉP is called the variational ball of radius Œ¥ùõø\delta around PùëÉP.

Our first condition ensures that each source in the class is sufficiently close to an i.i.d. source, in an asymptotic sense. Define the kùëòkth Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-mixing coefficient of PŒ∏subscriptùëÉùúÉP_{\theta} [5] by

where œÉ‚Äã(X‚àí‚àû0,Xk‚àû)ùúésubscriptsuperscriptùëã0subscriptsuperscriptùëãùëò\sigma(X^{0}_{-\infty},X^{\infty}_{k}) is the œÉùúé\sigma-field generated by {Xi}i‚â§0subscriptsubscriptùëãùëñùëñ0\{X_{i}\}_{i\leq 0} and {Xi}i‚â•ksubscriptsubscriptùëãùëñùëñùëò\{X_{i}\}_{i\geq k}, and PŒ∏‚àísubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùúÉP^{-}_{\theta} and PŒ∏+subscriptsuperscriptùëÉùúÉP^{+}_{\theta} are the marginal distributions of {Xi}i‚â§0subscriptsubscriptùëãùëñùëñ0\{X_{i}\}_{i\leq 0} and {Xi}i>0subscriptsubscriptùëãùëñùëñ0\{X_{i}\}_{i>0}, respectively. An i.i.d. source has Œ≤‚Äã(k)‚â°0,‚àÄkùõΩùëò0for-allùëò\beta(k)\equiv 0,\forall k; if Œ≤‚Äã(k)‚ü∂k‚Üí‚àû0superscript‚ü∂‚ÜíùëòùõΩùëò0\beta(k)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle k\to\infty}}{{\longrightarrow}}0, the source is called Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-mixing.

Condition 1. The sources in {PŒ∏:Œ∏‚ààŒõ}conditional-setsubscriptùëÉùúÉùúÉŒõ\{P_{\theta}:\theta\in\Lambda\} are algebraically Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-mixing:

The second condition ensures that the parametrization of the sources is sufficiently smooth.

Condition 2. Let dn‚Äã(Œ∏,Œ∏‚Ä≤)subscriptùëëùëõùúÉsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤d_{n}(\theta,\theta^{\prime}) denote the variational distance between PŒ∏nsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëõùúÉP^{n}_{\theta} and PŒ∏‚Ä≤nsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëõsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤P^{n}_{\theta^{\prime}}. for all Œ∏‚Ä≤superscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤\theta^{\prime} satisfying ‚ÄñŒ∏‚Ä≤‚àíŒ∏‚Äñ<Œ¥Œ∏normsuperscriptùúÉ‚Ä≤ùúÉsubscriptùõøùúÉ\|\theta^{\prime}-\theta\|<\delta_{\theta}, where ‚à•‚ãÖ‚à•\|\cdot\| denotes the Euclidean norm on ‚Ñùksuperscript‚Ñùùëò\mathbb{R}^{k}.

This condition is met, for instance, if the asymptotic Fisher information matrix I‚Äã(Œ∏)ùêºùúÉI(\theta) exists for all Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda (under some technical assumptions on the densities pŒ∏nsubscriptsuperscriptùëùùëõùúÉp^{n}_{\theta}). Finally, we impose a learnability condition. To state it we need some facts on Vapnik‚ÄìChervonenkis classes (see, e.g., [4, 5]). Let (ùíµ,ùíú)ùíµùíú({\cal Z},{\cal A}) be a measurable space. Given a collection ùíûùíû{\cal C} of measurable subsets of ùíµùíµ{\cal Z}, its Vapnik-Chervonenkis (VC) dimension ùñµ‚Äã(ùíû)ùñµùíû{\sf V}({\cal C}) is defined as the largest integer nùëõn for which

maxxn‚ààùí≥n‚Å°|{(1{x1‚ààA},‚ãØ,1{xn‚ààA}):A‚ààùíû}|=2n;subscriptsuperscriptùë•ùëõsuperscriptùí≥ùëõconditional-setsubscript1subscriptùë•1ùê¥‚ãØsubscript1subscriptùë•ùëõùê¥ùê¥ùíûsuperscript2ùëõ\max_{x^{n}\in{\cal X}^{n}}|\{(1_{\{x_{1}\in A\}},\cdots,1_{\{x_{n}\in A\}}):A\in{\cal C}\}|=2^{n};\vspace{-4pt} (1)

Condition 3. For n‚àà‚Ñïùëõ‚Ñïn\in\mathbb{N}, let ùíúnsubscriptùíúùëõ{\cal A}_{n} consist of all sets of the form

(ùíúnsubscriptùíúùëõ{\cal A}_{n} is the so-called Yatracos class defined by {pŒ∏n}subscriptsuperscriptùëùùëõùúÉ\{p^{n}_{\theta}\}, see [4] and references therein). Theorem 1

Suppose Conditions 1‚Äì3 are satisfied. Then for every Œª,Œ∑>0ùúÜùúÇ0\lambda,\eta>0 there exists a sequence {C‚àón,mn}n‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõùëõ‚Ñï\{C^{n,m_{n}}_{*}\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}} of variable-rate vector quantizers with memory lengths mn=n‚Äã(n+‚åàn(2+Œ∑)/r‚åâ)subscriptùëöùëõùëõùëõsuperscriptùëõ2ùúÇùëüm_{n}=n(n+\lceil n^{(2+\eta)/r}\rceil), such that

LŒ∏‚Äã(C‚àón,mn,Œª)‚àíinfminfCn,mLŒ∏‚Äã(Cn,m,Œª)=O‚Äã(Vn‚Äãlog‚Å°nn)subscriptùêøùúÉsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõùúÜsubscriptinfimumùëösubscriptinfimumsuperscriptùê∂ùëõùëösubscriptùêøùúÉsuperscriptùê∂ùëõùëöùúÜùëÇsubscriptùëâùëõùëõùëõL_{\theta}(C^{n,m_{n}}_{*},\lambda)-\inf_{m}\inf_{C^{n,m}}L_{\theta}(C^{n,m},\lambda)=O\left(\sqrt{\frac{V_{n}\log n}{n}}\right)\vspace{-4pt}

for all Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda. Moreover, for each nùëõn, the binary description produced by the encoder is such that the decoder can identify the nùëõn-dimensional marginal of the active source up to a variational ball of radius O‚Äã(Vn‚Äãlog‚Å°n/n)ùëÇsubscriptùëâùëõùëõùëõO\big{(}\sqrt{V_{n}\log n/n}\big{)} almost surely.

That is, for each n,Œ∏ùëõùúÉn,\theta the code C‚àón,mnsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõC^{n,m_{n}}_{*}, which is independent of Œ∏ùúÉ\theta, performs almost as well as the best finite-memory quantizer with block length nùëõn that can be designed with full knowledge of PŒ∏nsubscriptsuperscriptùëÉùëõùúÉP^{n}_{\theta}. Thus, as far as compression goes, our scheme can compete with all finite-memory variable-rate quantizers, with the additional bonus of allowing the decoder to identify the active source in an asymptotically optimal manner. Recalling the discussion of Lagrangian optimality in Section¬†II, we see that Theorem¬†1 immediately implies the following:

Corollary 2

The sequence {C‚àón,mn}n‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõùëõ‚Ñï\{C^{n,m_{n}}_{*}\}_{n\in\mathbb{N}} is weakly minimax universal222See [6] for other notions of universality for lossy codes. for {PŒ∏:Œ∏‚ààŒõ}conditional-setsubscriptùëÉùúÉùúÉŒõ\{P_{\theta}:\theta\in\Lambda\}, i.e., for every Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda, LŒ∏0‚Äã(C‚àón,mn,Œª)‚ÜíLŒ∏‚Äã(Œª)‚ÜísubscriptùêøsubscriptùúÉ0subscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõùúÜsubscriptùêøùúÉùúÜL_{\theta_{0}}(C^{n,m_{n}}_{*},\lambda)\to L_{\theta}(\lambda) as n‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùëõn\to\infty.

IV The proof of Theorem¬†1

The main idea. It suffices to construct a universal scheme that can compete with all zero-memory codes; that is, we need to show that there exists a sequence {C‚àón,mn}subscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõ\{C^{n,m_{n}}_{*}\} of codes, such that LŒ∏‚Äã(C‚àón,mn,Œª)‚àíL^Œ∏n‚Äã(Œª)=O‚Äã(Vn‚Äãlog‚Å°n/n)subscriptùêøùúÉsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõùúÜsubscriptsuperscript^ùêøùëõùúÉùúÜùëÇsubscriptùëâùëõùëõùëõL_{\theta}(C^{n,m_{n}}_{*},\lambda)-\widehat{L}^{n}_{\theta}(\lambda)=O(\sqrt{V_{n}\log n/n}) for all Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda.

Formally, the code C‚àón,mnsubscriptsuperscriptùê∂ùëõsubscriptùëöùëõC^{n,m_{n}}_{*} is comprised by the following maps: (1) the parameter estimator Œ∏~:ùí≥mn‚ÜíŒõ:~ùúÉ‚Üísuperscriptùí≥subscriptùëöùëõŒõ\widetilde{\theta}:{\cal X}^{m_{n}}\rightarrow\Lambda; (2) the parameter encoder g~:Œõ‚ÜíùíÆ~:~ùëî‚ÜíŒõ~ùíÆ\widetilde{g}:\Lambda\rightarrow\widetilde{{\cal S}}, where ùíÆ~={0‚Äãs‚Äã(i)}i‚àà‚Ñï‚à™{1}~ùíÆsubscript0ùë†ùëñùëñ‚Ñï1\widetilde{{\cal S}}=\{0s(i)\}_{i\in\mathbb{N}}\cup\{1\}; (3) the parameter decoder œà~:ùíÆ~‚ÜíŒõ:~ùúì‚Üí~ùíÆŒõ\widetilde{\psi}:\widetilde{{\cal S}}\rightarrow\Lambda. V Examples

Gaussian process with zero mean and unit variance. For Condition 2, it can be shown that, for each Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda, the asymptotic Fisher information matrix I‚Äã(Œ∏)ùêºùúÉI(\theta) exists (and is nonsingular) [12]. Thus, Condition 2 can be met. Hidden Markov processes. A hidden Markov process is a discrete-time finite-state homogeneous Markov chain, observed through a discrete-time memoryless channel (see [13] and references therein). Let ùë∫={Si}i‚àà‚Ñ§ùë∫subscriptsubscriptùëÜùëñùëñ‚Ñ§\boldsymbol{S}=\{S_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} be a stationary ergodic Markov process with M<‚àûùëÄM<\infty states and the (unique) stationary distribution œÄ=(œÄ1,‚Ä¶,œÄM)ùúãsubscriptùúã1‚Ä¶subscriptùúãùëÄ\pi=(\pi_{1},\ldots,\pi_{M}). Let ai‚Äãj=‚Ñô‚Å°(St+1=j|St=i)subscriptùëéùëñùëó‚ÑôsubscriptùëÜùë°1conditionalùëósubscriptùëÜùë°ùëña_{ij}=\operatorname{{\mathbb{P}}}(S_{t+1}=j|S_{t}=i), 1‚â§i,j‚â§Mformulae-sequence1ùëñùëóùëÄ1\leq i,j\leq M, denote the corresponding one-step transition probabilities. Let ùí≥=‚Ñùdùí≥superscript‚Ñùùëë{\cal X}=\mathbb{R}^{d}, and consider a discrete-time memoryless channel with input alphabet ùíÆ=‚ñ≥{1,‚Ä¶,M}superscript‚ñ≥ùíÆ1‚Ä¶ùëÄ{\cal S}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\{1,\ldots,M\} and output alphabet ùí≥ùí≥{\cal X}, specified by a collection {p(‚ãÖ|s):s‚ààùíÆ}\{p(\cdot|s):s\in{\cal S}\} of probability densities on ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d} w.r.t. the Lebesgue measure. The output process ùëø={Xi}i‚àà‚Ñ§ùëøsubscriptsubscriptùëãùëñùëñ‚Ñ§\boldsymbol{X}=\{X_{i}\}_{i\in\mathbb{Z}} is the source of interest.

Let us assume that the channel transition densities are known, and that the one-step transition probabilities of the underlying Markov chain ùë∫ùë∫\boldsymbol{S} are known to be strictly positive and bounded from below by some a0>0subscriptùëé00a_{0}>0. Under these assumptions, for any Œ∏‚ààŒõùúÉŒõ\theta\in\Lambda the underlying Markov process ùë∫ùë∫\boldsymbol{S} is exponentially Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-mixing [14]. The pair process {(Si,Ui)}subscriptùëÜùëñsubscriptùëàùëñ\{(S_{i},U_{i})\} is exponentially Œ≤ùõΩ\beta-mixing, and therefore so is ùëøùëø\boldsymbol{X}. This establishes Condition¬†1.
